question: I notice waves look different sometimes - some are chaotic and others more uniform. What's the difference between seas and swells?
generated_answer:
Seas and swells are two types of surface waves on the ocean, differentiated by their origin and characteristics.

Seas are short-period waves that are still being created by winds or are very close to the area in which they were generated. They are typically short-crested and irregular, with a more disturbed surface compared to swells. Seas are often associated with local wind conditions and can be quite chaotic.

Swells, on the other hand, are waves that have moved out of the generating area, far from the influence of the winds that made them. They have smooth, well-defined crests and relatively long periods. Swells are more uniform and regular than seas because wave energy becomes more organized as it travels long distances. Longer period waves move faster than short period waves, and reach distant sites first. As a result, swells tend to be longer, smoother, and more uniform than seas.

In summary, the main difference between seas and swells is their origin and the distance they have traveled. Seas are closer to their source and are more chaotic, while swells have traveled further and are more organized and uniform.
ground_truth_answer: Seas are short-crested, irregular waves that are still being created by winds or are very close to their generation area. Swells, on the other hand, have moved far from where they were generated and form longer, smoother, more uniform waves because wave energy becomes more organized as it travels long distances.
